text: What I'd like to do is start with these four bullet points that will offer a summary of the equity expansion proposal. text: Second,  to provide oversight and implementation of the anti-racism policy and other equity regulations involving ongoing reviews and updates. This requires curriculum development and training from an equity and an anti-racism lens. Third,  We are very happy to announce that all contracts of new hires effective 2021 will require culturally responsive teaching training, and they must meet the micro-credential or certification requirements within three years to maintain continuous contract status. This will certainly have an impact on the culture of Albemarle County Public Schools. And fourth,  The inclusion of an equity and anti-racism framework will help address a systemic transformation of racial and equity achievement disparities. This will allow for a concentrated focus on identifying as well changing division philosophies, division policies, programs, and practices recognized as barriers.  Next slide. We believe this equity proposal as a part of requesting the three FTEs to expand the equity specialist team from three to six staff members  will address four of the five division objectives and the three strategic priorities while advancing the division's strategic plan. We believe this request is specific to training all staff to engage every student by placing value on their social and cultural experiences as relevant to how and what they teach.  This approach centers on strengthening the student, the family, and community partnerships.  We believe the results produce a best practice to identify and develop students' interests in understanding the value of teaching to the whole child. We also believe this will naturally reduce opportunity and achievement gaps, which will optimize resources while maximizing the tier one teaching and learning process. You might call that avoiding an achievement gap.  Next slide, please. Now, this slide will help us understand the focus, our focus over the past 12 years. I will speak to these reference points from the bottom left of the slide to the top when you see the anti-racism orientation. In 1999,  Albemarle County Public Schools was one of the first school divisions in the state to staff a diversity coordinator and allotted stipends to diversity resource teachers in each school to lead courageous conversations about equity and inclusion. In 2008, a resource utilization study recommended a downsizing of central office staff positions. The, unfortunately,  the diversity, or fortunately, the diversity coordinator position was eliminated. Rather than discontinuing this critical work, the focus shifted from courageous conversations, and that's the fortunate part, to culturally responsive teaching to address one of the three goals of eliminating achievement gaps. Now, from a historical perspective,  the culturally responsive teaching model evolved from the research of Geneva Gay's book, Culturally Responsive Teaching, Theory, Research, and Practice, Bonnie Davis's work of How to Teach Students Who Don't Look Like You, and the research of Zoretta Hammond, Culturally Responsive Teaching and the Brain. Now, in 2009, the work was field tested  with MQ, which stands for Math Men Mission. And this program was offered through a summer academy, a community partnership initiative with the 100 Black men of Central Virginia to prepare African American male middle school students to enroll and complete Algebra I by grade eight. There were only two  African American males enrolled in the seventh grade and eighth grade algebra classes offered in the five middle schools in that year. MQ teachers were hired and retrained to teach to and through the culture of the students enrolled. Parents participation was a required partnership.  Learning occurred naturally through a culturally relevant and collectivist approach centered on the student, not on the teacher.  High expectations were modeled by framing the student as scholars of brilliance and taught at Bloom's Taxonomy's highest levels. Subsequently, the National School Boards Association recognized Albemarle County Public Schools in 2011 and 2013 with the Magna Award for Innovative Best Practices for Closing Achievement Gaps. In 2015,  The culturally responsive teaching model introduced an assessment tool to validate the relationship of CRT curriculum design, professional development training, and personalized follow-up coaching. This assessment involves  the submission of a maximum of a 10-page portfolio that documents the evidence of teacher and student growth over the course of a school year. Each candidate presents their evidence to a team, generally four or five staff members, who are assessors to validate the impact on student achievement.  This process requires intensive staff time personalized to each candidate simply because every student is different. Now, between 2015 and 2018, the organizational structure expanded to include an equity leadership team, school-based equity teams in each school,  and you, the school board, approved two equity specialist positions and the CRT micro-credential was introduced. Between 2016 and 2018, about 500 staff were trained in the three culturally responsive teaching modules, of which 17 educators received certification and 13 completed the micro-credential.  Now, in 2019, you approved staffing for a third equity specialist honoring our growth. At the same time,  The anti-racism policy was adopted and the anti-racism steering committee was created to implement the 22 regulations of the policy. That same year, the equity team facilitated multiple community conversations as directed by you, the school board. This work has expanded this year to rolling out an unprecedented challenge of deinstitutionalized racism.  All staff are engaged in the courageous conversation about race book study and the orientation training on the anti-racism policy. This slide truly represents a progressive school division, and I thank you as visionary leaders. Next slide, please.  Now, this graph represents a snapshot of services offered since 2015-16 school year and projections through 2024 to understand the increasing demand for services. The light blue dotted line illustrates the professional development training growth  from 2015 to 2024. For example, in 2016, there were 12 educators to receive the required training on the three characteristics or the modulus of culturally responsive teaching. Now, this peaked to about 170 in 2019 and will exceed a modest projection of 300  by 2023. Now, the orange line tracks the number of educators who completed the CRT micro-credential since its introduction in 2017. We are projecting growth from the original 13 in 2017 to close to 288 candidates by 2023.  The purple line tracks the number of educators who completed the CRT certification since its introduction in 2015-2016. For example, there were 12 educators to experience the modular training throughout the year. Four of the 12 completed the process and received the certification.  Now we are projecting growth from the original four in 2015 to close to 160 candidates, 61 candidates by 2023. Keep in mind, the equity team must be prepared to coach and assess about 449 candidates engaged in the micro-credential and certification by 2023.  Now we want you to focus your attention on the far right-hand side of the slide. These items represent three of the many impactful unplanned, unplanned spinoff initiatives that occur because of things such as a new policy or policy revision or directives from the school board or our superintendent or a strategic plan initiative.  These initiatives, these new initiatives, always require planning, follow up action steps, and accountability oversight to receive those long term outcomes. Mr. Foley's team worked with the equity team over several months to prepare, and they are now working on smaller group follow-up training sessions. Next slide, please.  Now, here are examples of inputs and activities that will require immediate attention. By June 2021, the following deliverables will be completed for establishing the planning foundation. This process actually began in November 2020 by considering requests for services and the resources we manage well. One thing we determined is that our biggest resource is our social capital or the staff members in the school division who support this work because they believe in the work.
